name: 6-nitro-2-phenyl-3H-indol-3-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3395
Reason: 6-nitro-2-phenyl-3H-indol-3-one has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components. Starting with the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C, we have substantial structural components to consider: (1) Two phenyl groups, which add approximately +20°C due to increasing molecular weight and van der Waals interactions; (2) The nitro group introduces a strong withdrawing group, raising the melting point by approximately +50°C; (3) The indole ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and pi-pi interactions, estimated at around +20°C; and (4) The methyl group can lower the melting point by approximately -10°C due to reducing the molecular weight and steric hindrance.
